#Text=CHAPTER XVIII
#Text=That was a thought almost continuously in his mind , even when he was hardest at work ; and , as the days went on and he could not free himself , he became querulous about it .
#Text=“ I guess I 'm the biggest dang fool alive , ” he told his wife as they sat together one evening .
#Text=“ I got plenty else to bother me , without worrying my head off about what HE thinks .
#Text=I ca n't help what he thinks ; it 's too late for that .
#Text=So why should I keep pestering myself about it ? ”
#Text=“ It 'll wear off , Virgil , ” Mrs. Adams said , reassuringly .
#Text=She was gentle and sympathetic with him , and for the first time in many years he would come to sit with her and talk , when he had finished his day 's work .
#Text=He had told her , evading her eye , “ Oh , I do n't blame you .
#Text=You did n't get after me to do this on your own account ; you could n't help it . ”
#Text=“ Yes ; but it do n't wear off , ” he complained .

#Text=“ This afternoon I was showing the men how I wanted my vats to go , and I caught my fool self standing there saying to my fool self , ' It 's funny I do n't hear how he feels about it from SOMEbody .
#Text=' I was saying it aloud , almost -- and it IS funny I do n't hear anything ! ”
#Text=“ Well , you see what it means , do n't you , Virgil ?
#Text=It only means he has n't said anything to anybody about it .
#Text=Do n't you think you 're getting kind of morbid over it ? ”
#Text=“ Maybe , maybe , ” he muttered .
#Text=“ Why , yes , ” she said , briskly .
#Text=“ You do n't realize what a little bit of a thing all this is to him .
#Text=It 's been a long , long while since the last time you even mentioned glue to him , and he 's probably forgotten everything about it . ”
#Text=“ You 're off your base ; it is n't like him to forget things , ” Adams returned , peevishly .
#Text=“ He may seem to forget ' em , but he do n't . ”
#Text=“ But he 's not thinking about this , or you 'd have heard from him before now . ”
#Text=Her husband shook his head .
#Text=“ Ah , that 's just it ! ” he said .
#Text=“ Why HAVEN'T I heard from him ? ”
#Text=“ It 's all your morbidness , Virgil .
#Text=Look at Walter : if Mr. Lamb held this up against you , would he still let Walter stay there ?
#Text=Would n't he have discharged Walter if he felt angry with you ? ”
#Text=“ That dang boy ! ” Adams said .
#Text=“ If he WANTED to come with me now , I would n't hardly let him , What do you suppose makes him so bull-headed ? ”
#Text=“ But has n't he a right to choose for himself ? ” she asked .
#Text=“ I suppose he feels he ought to stick to what he thinks is sure pay .
#Text=As soon as he sees that you 're going to succeed with the glue-works he 'll want to be with you quick enough . ”
#Text=“ Well , he better get a little sense in his head , ” Adams returned , crossly .
#Text=“ He wanted me to pay him a three-hundred-dollar bonus in advance , when anybody with a grain of common sense knows I need every penny I can lay my hands on ! ”
#Text=“ Never mind , ” she said .
#Text=“ He 'll come around later and be glad of the chance . ”
#Text=“ He 'll have to beg for it then !
#Text=I wo n't ask him again . ”
#Text=“ Oh , Walter will come out all right ; you need n't worry .
#Text=And do n't you see that Mr. Lamb 's not discharging him means there 's no hard feeling against you , Virgil ? ”
#Text=“ I ca n't make it out at all , ” he said , frowning .
#Text=“ The only thing I can THINK it means is that J. A. Lamb is so fair-minded -- and of course he IS one of the fair-mindedest men alive I suppose that 's the reason he has n't fired Walter .
#Text=He may know , ” Adams concluded , morosely --
#Text=“he may know that 's just another thing to make me feel all the meaner : keeping my boy there on a salary after I 've done him an injury . ”
#Text=“ Now , now ! ” she said , trying to comfort him .
#Text=“ You could n't do anybody an injury to save your life , and everybody knows it . ”
#Text=“ Well , anybody ought to know I would n't WANT to do an injury , but this world is n't built so't we can do just what we want . ”
#Text=He paused , reflecting .
#Text=“ Of course there may be one explanation of why Walter 's still there : J. A. maybe has n't noticed that he IS there .
#Text=There 's so many I expect he hardly knows him by sight . ”
#Text=“ Well , just do quit thinking about it , ” she urged him .
#Text=“ It only bothers you without doing any good .
#Text=Do n't you know that ? ”
#Text=“ Do n't I , though ! ” he laughed , feebly .
#Text=“ I know it better'n anybody !
#Text=How funny that is : when you know thinking about a thing only pesters you without helping anything at all , and yet you keep right on pestering yourself with it ! ”
#Text=“ But WHY ? ” she said .
#Text=“ What 's the use when you know you have n't done anything wrong , Virgil ?
#Text=You said yourself you were going to improve the process so much it would be different from the old one , and you 'd REALLY have a right to it . ”

#Text=Adams had persuaded himself of this when he yielded ; he had found it necessary to persuade himself of it -- though there was a part of him , of course , that remained unpersuaded ; and this discomfiting part of him was what made his present trouble .
#Text=“ Yes , I know , ” he said .
#Text=“ That 's true , but I ca n't quite seem to get away from the fact that the principle of the process is a good deal the same --
#Text=well , it 's more'n that ; it 's just about the same as the one he hired Campbell and me to work out for him .
#Text=Truth is , nobody could tell the difference , and I do n't know as there IS any difference except in these improvements I 'm making .

#Text=Of course , the improvements do give me pretty near a perfect right to it , as a person might say ; and that 's one of the things I thought of putting in my letter to him ; but I was afraid he 'd just think I was trying to make up excuses , so I left it out .
#Text=I kind of worried all the time I was writing that letter , because if he thought I WAS just making up excuses , why , it might set him just so much more against me . ”
